awd_titl_txt: Approaches to Improved Synthesis Design:  Mechanistic and Synthetic Studies on New Annelation Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Paul A. Wender and co-workers of the Department of Chemistry at Stanford University will explore the development of new reactions, reagents and catalysts for organic synthesis. Studies will focus on new reagents for [5+2] cycloadditions and on a new family of reactivity relaying reagents for multicomponent [5+2]/[4+2] cycloadditions. Studies will also be directed at new strategies for carbon-carbon bond activation, a required step in a large class of cycloaddition reactions. Finally, studies will be directed at the development of the first transporter-catalyst conjugates for imaging and sensing in biological systems.     

This research is directed at the introduction of new reactions, catalysts and reagents for organic synthesis and thus at the introduction of new strategies for synthesizing molecules of interest for theoretical, medicinal, materials, imaging and energy research. New reactions, catalysts and reagents change how we think about bond construction, thereby providing options for improving step and time economy and providing greener if not ideal approaches to making molecules of scientific and societal value. Such advances provide the foundation for the pharmaceutical, agricultural, fine chemicals, materials science, environmental science, and energy industries and the fundamental tools for scientific research. The focus of this work on molecular processes also advances our basic knowledge of molecular structure and function, which in turn provides the foundation for the molecularization of science from molecular anthropology to molecular zoology. As evident from over 300 former coworkers trained in this program, many in leadership positions in academia and in industry, this research provides an exceptional training program for undergraduates, graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, including those from historically under-represented groups, and a source of inspiration and knowledge for others to use chemistry to address pressing and unsolved problems in medicine, materials, diagnostics and energy research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report: Our research is directed at advancing the understanding of molecular structure, mechanism and synthesis – the intellectual foundation of all molecular science from molecular anthropology to molecular zoology, and the training of future scientists and educators – critical goals for sustained existence on a planet increasingly challenged by population growth and environmental, health and other issues. This project was focused on plans for the design, discovery and development of new reactions, reagents, catalysts and strategies for organic synthesis. New reactions, reagents and reactivities enable new synthetic strategies, improve mechanistic understanding, and provide greener and safer if not ideal syntheses of targets of theoretical, materials, economic or medicinal value. Emphasis is placed on catalyzed reactions that in the absence of catalysts are forbidden or difficult to achieve. Such reactions offer new ways to think about synthetic problems, new process options that avoid environmentally problematic steps, new ways to access novel materials and often new mechanisms and insights that add to our knowledge of bonding, structure, and reactivity. New reactions impact the whole of science, providing new ways to address problems at a molecular level.

 

Over the past 30 years our program has led to the invention of new reactions, catalysts and reagents, enabling new strategies for the synthesis of molecules of theoretical, imaging, materials, diagnostic and medicinal interest. Our work has inspired related studies in other laboratories on reactions and reagents that we introduced. During the recent grant period we advanced our studies on a new reaction class that we introduced in 1995. We also introduced two new classes of reagents that enable the construction of molecules in ways previously not known or possible. One reagent functions as an equivalent of butatriene, a chemical that would be hazardous to handle and would not lend itself to controllable reactions. Our new reagent avoids these safety, handling and selectivity issues and provides a novel way to assemble complex systems using back-to-back cycloadditions. This has been used, for example, to make new kinase inhibitors, molecules of potential use in medicine and research.

 

We have also invented an equivalent of tetramethylene methane (TMM). This reagent allows for back-to-back cycloadditions and in this case has been used to make a new and potentially general solvatochromic dye. Such dyes can be used to determine the viscosity, pH, and polarity of systems that they are associated with. They represent powerful tools to investigate the physical properties of living systems as required in a wide range of life science research.

 

This project has also produced a new concept and family of catalysts that work in water, enabling their use in the study of cellular processes and potentially in human therapy. These agents are designed to activate a pro-drug, thereby releasing an active drug at the site where the catalyst is located. This has the potential to change many types of human therapies as a localized catalyst could turn a pro-drug into a drug at only the site where the catalyst is found.

 

The project has also led to new insights into metal catalyzed cycloadditions. These theoretical studies supported by experiment change how we think about fundamental processes and thereby allow us to more efficiently make molecules of importance to science ad society. 

 

Several students were directly trained as part of this program but in addition all in the research group and many in other research groups learned more about synthesis and in particular function-oriented synthesis. Indeed the seminal work resulting from our studies has now provided the foundation for NSF and other agency supported research programs in many US institutions and institutions abroad, the latter including studies being conducted by research groups in China, Canada, Japan, France, Germany, Sweden and Spain. Over the years, our research program involved the training of over 350 coworkers with over 70 now in academia and many of the others in industry including the recent CEO of a major pharmaceutical company.

 

During this period the PI started a new course for undergraduates at Stanford entitled “Scientific Innovation and Communication”. This has been a spectacular success. It has led to the creation of two web sites, a Stanford undergraduate organization directed at science and communication, and what this year is intended to be a video site to capture science news. This has proven to be a powerful teaching and learning tool and it has enabled students at Stanford to share their excitement and interest in science with others. They have conducted research on their self-selected stories, interviewed leading experts in their selected topics from around the world and developed their own articles and videos. This has proven to be one of the most effective outreach programs I have seen or participated in. We intend to explore taking this to a wider indeed national audience in the future.


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Paul A Wender
